116.title: Red Flags
116.description: These red flags are things we don’t want to see in our peeps. Even when you think they are improper, don’t waste your time with a wrong group of people.
116.spr_content: - **Negative Attitude**: Exhibits disengagement, lack of motivation, integrity issues, resistance to learning.<hr />- **Incompatibility**: Misalignment with company culture; personality clashes with team members.<hr />- **Lack of Professionalism**: Shows unprofessional behaviors, such as tardiness, absenteeism, missed deadlines, poor communication.<hr />- **Poor Performance**: Fails to meet performance standards; struggles with task completion.<hr />- **Low Morale**: Contributes to decreased team morale; potentially toxic environment.<hr />- **High Turnover Rate**: Indicates possible poor hiring decisions; employee frequently leaves.

117.title: The OKR
117.description: How we use OKR to define goals
117.spr_content: - OKR: Management methodology; outcome-driven tracking framework.<hr />- Components:<hr />  - Object: goal to achieve.<hr />  - Key Results: measurable indicators of progress towards the objective.<hr />- Example:<hr />  - Objective: Build a strong backend team.<hr />  - Key Results: <hr />    - Hire 2 senior backend developers.<hr />    - Organize 1 training session per week.<hr />- OKR structure:<hr />  - Foundation level: company-wide objectives and key results.<hr />  - Team level: specific objectives for team actions.<hr />  - Individual level: personal objectives for team members.<hr />- Keys to OKR:<hr />  - Set quarterly and annually.<hr />  - Ensure key results are measurable with specific metrics.<hr />  - Utilize both top-down (company) and bottom-up (individual) approaches.<hr />  - Share all OKRs company-wide for transparency.<hr />  - Grade key results on a scale from 0 to 1 for progress tracking.<hr />  - Limit to maximum 5 objectives and 4 key results each quarter.<hr />- Benefits over KPIs:<hr />  - Increase clarity in objective alignment across all levels.<hr />  - Enhance focus on achieving the right results.<hr />  - Foster collaboration through shared objectives and accountability.<hr />- Application process:<hr />  1. Conduct brainstorming session for quarter objectives.<hr />  2. Communicate company-wide objectives.<hr />  3. Draft personal OKRs.<hr />- Utilization tool: Hygger Board for organizing and tracking OKRs.<hr />- Suggested readings for further understanding:<hr />  - Articles and video resources on OKR success and implementation.

118.title: The Dwarves Culture Handbook
118.description: For the past 5 years, we didn't have something called 'Culture Book'. Whenever a newbie steps in, it's natural to pick up the job and go with the flow. We hardly force them into other periodical office traps like team-bonding activities or late night drinks.
118.spr_content: - Absence of 'Culture Book' for past five years creates a flow-oriented work environment.  <hr />- Newbies adapt organically; no mandatory bonding activities.  <hr />- Informal celebrations: birthdays often lead to unexpected treat requests, showcasing camaraderie.  <hr />- Workplace lacks the idealized charm of nurturing and friendly interactions typically associated with other establishments.  <hr />- Employees may seek 'friendlier' environments outside the current culture when disillusioned.  <hr />- Engaging conversations are encouraged in key comfortable spaces: kitchen, sofa, balcony.  <hr />- Discord channels serve as a platform for casual interaction, especially for less socially inclined individuals.  <hr />- Reading the Dwarves Culture Handbook provides insight into organizational spirit and values.  <hr />- Handbook encapsulates beliefs and future aspirations of Dwarves Foundation, shaped by collective daily experiences.  <hr />- Key principles of the culture are craftsmanship, teamwork, and sustainability.  <hr />- The handbook evolves like software; welcomes contributions for ongoing improvement.  <hr />- Share and instill these values with new team members to enrich the culture.  <hr />- Continual adaptation and growth is essential for all members.

119.title: The Inner Circle
119.description: The concept of an "inner circle" within a company is not a new one, and at Dwarves, a software company founded by a group of engineers, this idea holds a significant value.
119.spr_content: - "Inner circle" concept prevalent in organizations, particularly at Dwarves.<hr />- Dwarves: software company founded by engineers focused on efficiency. <hr />- Value placed on individuals who efficiently ship software. <hr />- Respect and status within the company tied to contributions to shipping processes. <hr />- Differentiation between effective contributors and hindrances is clear. <hr />- Inner circle formed by respect, recognition, not status or past achievements.<hr />- Inclusion in inner circle based on consistent demonstration of value.<hr />- Impact on company's success is the primary criterion for inner circle membership.<hr />- Structure reflects broader organizational dynamics beyond Dwarves. <hr />- Efficiency and contribution are foundational to company success narratives.

120.title: Types Of Employees
120.description: Employees are either job-focused or mission-driven "mitochondria" who drive company growth. Prioritizing the latter through values interviews is key to startup success.
120.spr_content: - Two employee types exist: job-focused and mission-driven.  <hr />- Job-focused employees see work as transactional, valuing fair compensation and projects.  <hr />- Their contributions scale linearly; they are rational actors in the workplace.  <hr />- Mission-driven employees embody company values, passionate about the mission.  <hr />- They transcend job descriptions, adding exponential value to the company.  <hr />- They energize teams and are essential in startup growth stages.  <hr />- This group is akin to mitochondria, powering and sustaining organizational health.  <hr />- Early-stage startups rely on these individuals as core components; they evolve into leadership.  <hr />- Cherishing and cultivating them is critical for sustainable growth.  <hr />- Invest in relationships, maintaining awareness of this group's thoughts and sentiments.  <hr />- Conduct values interviews to align candidates with company culture and core values.  <hr />- Founders or existing mission-driven employees should conduct these interviews.  <hr />- Not interviewing for values results in suboptimal hiring, losing potential mission-driven talent.

121.title: Our Metrics For Performance Review
121.description: Performance is a final value that will be calculated from other metrics. This value will help to indicate how good all the activities we've done to make the company could grow.
121.spr_content: 1. **Performance (P)**: Calculated value reflecting company growth efforts; rated 1 (bad) to 5 (outstanding).<hr />   <hr />2. **Result (R)**: Measures output effectiveness; evaluated by project manager/team leader based on punctuality, workload, and quality.<hr /><hr />3. **Metrics**:<hr />   - **Punctuality**: Efficiency in timely task completion; assessed via logged hours/points.<hr />   - **Workload**: Level of effort contributed to the project.<hr />   - **Quality**: Work standard; driven by engagement and recognition of achievements.<hr /><hr />4. **Example Calculation**: Integrating punctuality, workload, and quality factors into performance score. Coefficients determine weighting.<hr /><hr />5. **Teamwork (T)**: Evaluates collaborative conduct; essential for success.<hr />   - **Proactivity**: Initiate actions without dependencies; approachability during work hours.<hr />   - **Cooperation**: Assist and share knowledge.<hr /><hr />6. **Firing Protocol**:<hr />   - **False Positives**: Hire who seem fit but do not align post-hire; fire quickly.<hr />   - **False Negatives**: Dismiss those not deemed fit but may excel; consider hiring them.<hr /><hr />7. **Performance Assessment**:<hr />   - **Incompetent Assholes**: Low performance; immediate termination.<hr />   - **Competent Assholes**: High performance with value misalignment; remediate or separate.<hr />   - **Incompetent Nice Guys**: Low performance, high culture fit; manage/training required.<hr />   - **Competent & Nice**: High performance and cultural fit; deserving of praise and advancement.<hr /><hr />8. **Dark Triad**: Key behavioral traits affecting team dynamics - psychopathy, machiavellianism, narcissism; breed manipulative actions for varying personal gains.<hr /><hr />9. **Startup Dynamics**:<hr />   - Focus: Solving real problems and contributing socially.<hr />   - Team Vision: A shared purpose guiding all actions; contributors over employees.<hr />   - Coordination: Essential for team efficiency; synchronization trumps individual skills.<hr /><hr />10. **Communication Metrics**:<hr />    - Daily transparency, effective presentations, clear writing, appropriate meeting engagement, resourceful problem-solving.<hr />    - **Helpfulness**: Fostering teamwork by supporting colleagues.<hr />    - **Leadership**: Initiating new ideas and guiding teammates.<hr /><hr />11. **Contribution (C)**:<hr />    - Encompasses broader external and cultural impacts; community engagement and innovation.<hr />    - Assessments include culture-building, forward-thinking, and technological adeptness.<hr /><hr />12. **Ranking (R)**: Focus on career development and growth metrics within the company scope. <hr /><hr />13. **Team Philosophy**: Emphasizes unity, strength in collaboration, and shared achievements while recognizing individualities.

122.title: MBTI Type ESTJ
122.description: All about the ESTJ personality type
122.spr_content: - ESTJ characteristics: thorough analysis, practical planning, process control, and responsibility.<hr />- Prefers structured, performance-driven environments with clear norms.<hr />- Values facts, details, and tangible products/services over concepts.<hr />- Desires clarity in roles, rules, and expectations; dislikes ambiguity and risk-taking.<hr />- Finds satisfaction in organized, high-stakes environments involving task/resource management.<hr />- Conducts detailed career exploration through facts, networking, logical evaluation, and values alignment.<hr />- Organizes effective job searches; balances job requirements with personal capabilities.<hr />- In interviews, highlights competencies with examples; needs to build connections without being overly dominant.<hr />- At work, ESTJs are dependable, decisive, detail-oriented, and aim for efficiency.<hr />- Support organizational structures and policies; prefer established methods for problem-solving.<hr />- Must be aware of potential inflexibility and the impact of their high standards on others.<hr />- On teams, they contribute energy, challenge peers, and expect commitment and efficiency.<hr />- Leaders organize plans for results, provide clear expectations, and encourage adherence to policies.<hr />- Communicate directly, favor logical discussions over small talk; may need to soften critiques.<hr />- Make decisions based on objective evaluation, past experiences, and consideration of impacts on others.<hr />- Experience stress when facing inefficiency, uncertainty, or perceived lack of control.<hr />- Stress responses may include withdrawal, emotional outbursts, rigidity, or work obsession.<hr />- Stress management strategies: talk about feelings, reassess goals, spend time alone, and reflect on situations.

123.title: Collaboration Guidelines
123.description: Guidelines for project collaboration between Dwarves and our Clients.
123.spr_content: - **Tools Overview**: Utilize Basecamp for project management and communication, Jira for sprint planning and tracking, Google Meet for meetings, and Github/Gitlab for source control; design with Figma/Sketch.<hr />- **Schedule**: Kick-off meeting (1 session), weekly or bi-weekly sprints, planning and review meetings each sprint, daily standups via communication channels.<hr />- **Meeting Notes**: Send within 30 minutes post Sprint planning and retrospective meetings.<hr />- **Project Management**:<hr />  - All members involved in Sprint planning.<hr />  - Milestones and features listed on Jira/Basecamp at kick-off.<hr />  - New requests go to Icebox/Backlog; bugs handled based on priority.<hr />  - Aim for “Potentially Shippable” software each Sprint.<hr />- **Design & Development**: <hr />  - Design team delivers UI elements (color palette, fonts, base components) before the start of each Sprint.<hr />- **Backend & Frontend Coordination**:<hr />  - Establish API documentation and environments; agree on naming conventions early.<hr />- **Quality Assurance**:<hr />  - Document bugs with specifics; utilize dedicated testing environments for frontend.<hr />- **Release Schedule**: Releases occur at Sprint end; hotfixes are ad-hoc, including semantic version tagging and release notes.<hr />- **Customer Feedback**: Direct feedback to respective team leads based on nature (Development, Sprint results, Pricing).<hr />- **Issues Management**:<hr />  - Four severity levels dictate response and resolution times, from critical (<30 mins) to minor (1 business day).<hr />- **Billing Process**: Invoices sent monthly; based on deployed resources and project type (Fixed-price or T&M), with necessary payment details provided.<hr />- **Payment Terms**: Clients have 10 business days to pay, penalties for late payments without prior written approval.<hr />- **Project Team Responsibilities**:<hr />  - **Team Lead**: Infrastructure and technical oversight, progress reporting.<hr />  - **Account Manager**: Client feedback management and relationship maintenance.<hr />  - **Project Manager**: Project standards implementation, deliverable production, risk management, and reporting.

124.title: MBTI Type ISTP
124.description: All about the ISTP personality type
124.spr_content: ### ISTP Work Environment and Career Insights  <hr /><hr />**Work Environment Preferences:**<hr />- Practical, skill mastery; tangible results.<hr />- Variety; transition in and out of activities.<hr />- Disregard for rules aids effective emergency responses.  <hr /><hr />**Career Satisfaction Characteristics:**<hr />- Technical application in practical settings.<hr />- Skill mastery for specific tasks.<hr />- Hands-on work; tool usage.<hr />- Clear project guidelines for concrete outcomes.<hr />- Collaboration with respected, competent individuals.<hr />- Opportunities for problem-solving and crisis management.<hr />- Independent work with minimal supervision.<hr />- Challenging, enjoyable tasks with little oversight.  <hr /><hr />**Career Exploration Behavior:**<hr />- Compile specific career facts; focus on current and predictive opportunities.<hr />- Take time to assess options; uncertainty about choices.  <hr /><hr />**Job Search Dynamics:**<hr />- Collect job-related info; organize structured job search plans.<hr />- Extra effort required; convey experience through documentation.<hr />- Risk-taking; adapting to new job possibilities, networking selectively.  <hr /> <hr />**Interview Behavior:**<hr />- Quiet, reserved demeanor; straightforward responses.<hr />- Practice discussing skills; cautious about detail and future scenarios.  <hr /><hr />**Workplace Traits:**<hr />- Concentration on interesting projects; organized information.<hr />- Attraction to tangible products; focus on active task completion.<hr />- Preference for solo work; mutual respect for competent colleagues.<hr />- Potential rule-breaking for efficiency; minimize unnecessary discussions.<hr />- Flexibility in workload responses; calm under pressure.  <hr /><hr />**Awareness Needs at Work:**<hr />- Additional planning time needed; anticipate future possibilities.<hr />- Risk of being easily distracted by new projects; patience for task completion; might appear disorganized.<hr />- Boredom with routine; benefit from improved organization.<hr />- Focus on immediate solutions; inclination for spontaneity may appear irresponsible.  <hr /> <hr />**Team Dynamics:**<hr />- Provide necessary data; organize and analyze efficiently.<hr />- Logical conflict resolution; motivate teammates; fair treatment.  <hr /><hr />**Potential Team Challenges:**<hr />- Avoidance of interpersonal conflicts; irritation from focus on specifics.<hr />- Frustration with overly emotional teammates; need for appreciation and rapport-building.  <hr /><hr />**Leadership Style:**<hr />- Quiet, example-setting approach; freedom from rigid policies.<hr />- Information compilation to persuade; logical decision-making; expect equal contributions.  <hr /><hr />**Communication Style:**<hr />- Preference for logical, objective information; minimal unnecessary communication.<hr />- Reliance on non-verbal cues; dislike of superficiality.  <hr /><hr />**Communication Awareness Needs:**<hr />- Intentional sharing of thoughts; comfort in emotional expression.<hr />- Consideration for others’ feelings; active listening and feedback provision.  <hr /><hr />**Decision-Making Approach:**<hr />- Decisions based on tangible data; rational evaluation of options.<hr />- Examination of broader implications; integration of personal values.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Triggers:**<hr />- Emotion control issues; strict guidelines; perceived incompetence of others.<hr />- Illogical situations; overwhelmed by tasks; excessive sociability.<hr />- Emotional co-worker interactions.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Response:**<hr />- Heightened focus on logic; resistance to help.<hr />- Sensitivity to others' perceptions; feelings of alienation.<hr />- Potential emotional outbursts under extreme stress.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Reduction Strategies:**<hr />- Analyze facts for clarity; engage in independent, divertive activities.<hr />- Focus on personal values; reenergize through solitude.<hr />- Disregard others' perceptions.

125.title: The Four Preferences
125.description: The four preferences in MBTI personalities
125.spr_content: 1. **Extraversion vs. Introversion**: Distinction between external engagement (extraverting) and internal reflection (introverting). <hr />   - Extraverting activities: talking, listening, cooking, working on cars.<hr />   - Introverting activities: reading, contemplating, self-awareness, problem-solving.<hr />   - Preference influences life's direction and source of energy.<hr /><hr />2. **Sensing vs. Intuition**: Differences in information gathering methods.<hr />   - Sensing: concrete data absorption via senses (tasting, observing changes, memorizing, following plans).<hr />   - Intuition: abstract possibilities and meanings from gathered data (innovation, future implications, perceiving underlying meanings).<hr />   - Preference affects trust in information gathering.<hr /><hr />3. **Thinking vs. Feeling**: Two criteria for decision-making.<hr />   - Thinking: logic and reason-focused decisions (research products, fairness, adherence to rules).<hr />   - Feeling: subjective, value-based decisions (personal liking, emotional considerations, environmental preferences).<hr />   - Balance between both leads to easier decisions; conflict brings dominant preference to the fore.<hr /><hr />4. **Judging vs. Perceiving**: Attitude towards the external environment and day-to-day living.<hr />   - Judging: preference for order, closure, and planning (to-do lists, scheduling, forming judgments).<hr />   - Perceiving: preference for flexibility and spontaneity (postponing decisions, spontaneous actions, last-minute tasks).<hr />   - Differences can create challenges in relationships; complementary dynamics possible in mixed preference partnerships.

126.title: Go The Extra Mile
126.description: A couple days ago, I was asked if I were ever a product person, what would I do to make the best out of it. It took me a while. I mean, I've never walked in this shoe before. Wth is a product person? I wondered. And I started digging. Here it is, "Making sure your product/ thing shipped out flawlessly." A perfectionist mindset.
126.spr_content: - A product person ensures flawless product delivery. <hr />- Requires a perfectionist mindset; intriguing yet challenging. <hr />- Quality is paramount; no one wants poor products. <hr />- Poor creations lead to dissatisfaction; the goal is to create excellence. <hr />- Exceed expectations; a commitment to constant improvement is crucial. <hr />- Regularly evaluate and optimize previous work for growth. <hr />- Attention to detail is essential; little things shape the overall quality. <hr />- A polished product reflects strong work ethic and self-regard. <hr />- The principle "How you treat yourself is how others will treat you" applies to products as well. <hr />- The extra mile stems from genuine passion, not overwork. <hr />- True commitment elevates the quality of a product. <hr />- Focus on quality over quantity; one well-crafted product is better than multiple subpar ones.

127.title: Constructive Feedback
127.description: It's in human nature to instantly lose their mind when things get hard, and somehow they split nasty things that can't be undone. So, to reduce the ratio of unnecessary conflicts, let's make the feedback great again.
127.spr_content: - Human nature is prone to emotional responses under stress, causing irreversible damage in conflicts.<hr />- Aim to reduce unnecessary conflicts by enhancing the quality of feedback.<hr />- Establish clear timeframes for listening and questioning to facilitate effective communication.<hr />- Recognize that respect for others’ time fosters receptiveness to your ideas.<hr />- Address all levels of problems, both minor and major.<hr />- Transform expressions of concern into questions that encourage understanding.<hr />- Effective feedback inspires motivation across diverse ages and skill levels.<hr />- Distinguish between effective and ineffective feedback:<hr />  - State the problem clearly.<hr />  - Offer solutions with humility.<hr />  - Visualize feasible impacts.<hr />- Ideal colleagues possess the ability to provide honest critiques and willingness to assist in improvement.<hr />- Value straightforward feedback for its role in bridging gaps between drafts and final products.<hr />- Feedback should be constructive, promoting growth rather than judgment.<hr />- Use constructive phrasing to facilitate improvement, such as suggesting alternatives rather than expressing frustration directly.

128.title: Compliance Check Process
128.description: A comprehensive compliance program encompassing monthly audits, transparent progress tracking, and consequences for non-compliance, aiming to foster accountability and transparency within the team.
128.spr_content: - **Compliance Management Framework**: Systematic approach to ensure adherence to standards.<hr />- **Checklist Storage**: Master compliance checklist archived; execution tracked via clones named as df-compliance-<field>-<mm><yyyy>.<hr />- **Monthly Execution**: 30% of projects selected monthly for compliance checks; cloned checklist per project stored alongside master.<hr />- **Project Sheets**: Individual project compliance sheets housed within the execution files.<hr />- **Task Assignment**: Compliance PIC creates actionable items in Basecamp for project PICs.<hr />- **Verification Process**: Double-check outcomes via direct questions or peer comparisons.<hr />- **Responsibility for Action**: Project PIC is accountable for addressing compliance issues found.<hr />- **Reporting**: Compliance PIC compiles a report for team dissemination during engineering meeting.<hr />- **Recognition System**: Projects earn "Fame" for exemplary compliance and "Shame" for deficiencies.<hr />- **Training Requirement**: Mandatory training for incomplete or unexplained checklist categories.<hr />- **Probation Impact**: Compliance completion is essential for new hires to pass probation.<hr />- **Transparency Principle**: Key to effective auditing; encompasses public awareness of processes and consequences.<hr />- **Communication Steps**: Audit process includes clear announcements, tracking progress, weekly updates, and accountability measures.<hr />- **Public Accountability**: Collective progress tracking fosters motivation and proactive engagement among team members.<hr />- **Long-term Engagement**: Consistent compliance work builds a culture of accountability and integration into workflows.

129.title: MBTI Type INTJ
129.description: All about the INTJ personality type
129.spr_content: ### Preferred Work Environment<hr />- Values expertise and innovation.<hr />- Seeks complex problem-solving opportunities.<hr />- Achievement-driven, with intellectual challenges.<hr />  <hr />### Career Exploration Influences<hr />- INTJ traits lead to specific career satisfaction.<hr />- Prefers analytical, creative, and knowledge-driven roles.<hr />- Enjoys autonomy, continuous learning, and efficiency improvements.<hr />- Sets long-term goals; plans and pivots as needed.<hr />- Uses objective evaluations for career assessment.<hr /><hr />### Career Development Insights<hr />- Involves adapting to diverse workplace dynamics.<hr />- Development arises from embracing non-preferred traits.<hr />- Recognizes strengths (organized, visionary) and challenges (impatience, rigidity).<hr />  <hr />### Job Search and Interview<hr />- Crafts unique job search strategies and adapts applications.<hr />- Displays confidence, but must avoid arrogance.<hr />- Open to feedback, should articulate contributions clearly.<hr /><hr />### Work Characteristics<hr />- Organized, productive, focused on long-term vision.<hr />- Prefers autonomous, uninterrupted environments.<hr />- Strives for high standards in all projects, expects similar commitment from others.<hr />- Tends to overlook practical nuances or reevaluate decisions.<hr /><hr />### Team Dynamics<hr />- Provides fresh perspectives and organized task management.<hr />- Advocates for ideas but struggles with teamwork dynamics.<hr />- Can be frustrated by perceived incompetence.<hr /><hr />### Leadership Style<hr />- Naturally inclined to lead and transform concepts into reality.<hr />- Motivates self and others towards shared objectives.<hr /><hr />### Communication Preferences<hr />- Favors direct, task-oriented dialogue; seldom shares personal views.<hr />- Critical approach; may seem impatient with misunderstandings.<hr /><hr />### Decision-Making Approach<hr />- Employs logical analysis; independent in choice-making.<hr />- Must consider personal impacts alongside logical outcomes.<hr /><hr />### Stress Triggers<hr />- Aversion to unplanned changes or incompetence.<hr />- Finds disorganization stressful; aversion to deception.<hr />  <hr />### Coping Mechanisms<hr />- Engages in distracting activities to avoid stress.<hr />- Benefits from reflection, physical activity, and delegating tasks.<hr />- Gains perspective through task completion and social connection.

130.title: Focus On Software Delivery
130.description: Focus on shipping when you are struggling with what to do next to be better as a software engineer. When you ship something new, users will try out your build and give you feedback.
130.spr_content: - Prioritize shipping over perfection when improving as a software engineer.<hr />- Release products to gain user feedback; it provides real-world insights.<hr />- Expect initial feedback to reveal bugs, flow issues, and known problems.<hr />- Frustration from user feedback can be advantageous; it informs improvement.<hr />- Overthinking delays progress; focus on delivery instead.<hr />- Myths surrounding software quality dissolve post-shipping.<hr />- Team workflows and tool choices are secondary to user-centric delivery.<hr />- Quality assessment occurs after product release, not before.<hr />- Essential questions to consider: <hr />  - What will we ship?<hr />  - What does the end product entail?<hr />  - What are user perceptions and expectations?<hr />  - Will users find it helpful and engaging?<hr />- Delivery is paramount; understand the core of what to build.<hr />- Obstacles to delivery hinder success; address any blockers decisively.

131.title: Delegate Work Not Responsibility
131.description: Delegating work does not absolve you of responsibility. In the case of a failure, the blame is all yours. Investors will go after the CEO, even if an intern made the mistake that hurt the company.
131.spr_content: - Technology alone is insufficient for organizational scaling; effective delegation is crucial.  <hr />- Delegation doesn’t relieve you of ultimate responsibility; blame trace always leads to CEO.  <hr />- Choosing unskilled individuals for tasks reflects poor judgment in delegation.  <hr />- Use of "do it yourself" indicates a need for growth in leadership and delegation skills.  <hr />- Clearly articulate tasks to team members; never assume understanding.  <hr />- Trust is essential in delegation; avoid micromanaging, or reevaluate task assignation.  <hr />- Communicate challenges and pitfalls to empower successful completion of tasks.  <hr />- Teaching is a key aspect of delegation; share insights and best practices.  <hr />- Lead in communication; mutual clarity is essential for effective collaboration.  <hr />- If trust is lacking and development investment is absent, consider employee replacement.  <hr />- Unreliable team members can hinder organizational progress; address or remove.

132.title: Beyond The Title
132.description: We want to make impacts or influence people in some ways. That doesn't happen if we wait for the right moment because there isn't. Taking the shot means opening the door to mistakes and failures, and that's a good thing. We learn from them.
132.spr_content: 1. Employment dilemma: <hr />   - Pay correlates directly with defined effort levels.<hr />   - Fixed pay leads to minimized effort; job descriptions limit exploration.<hr />   - Mindset fosters mediocrity; potential untested.<hr /><hr />2. Culture of initiative:<hr />   - Value creation over pay expectation is prioritized.<hr />   - Long-term thinking, upfront investment yields future returns.<hr />   - Flexibility in strategy enhances sustainability.<hr /><hr />3. Growth through risk:<hr />   - Impact requires action; perfect timing is a myth.<hr />   - Embracing failure leads to learning and personal development.<hr />   - Idleness hinders growth; seek new opportunities within the organization.<hr /><hr />4. Continuous improvement: <hr />   - Value teamwork; collaboration exceeds individual excellence.<hr />   - Support team goals; communicate constructively.<hr />   - Be reliable and contribute positively.<hr /><hr />5. Knowledge sharing:<hr />   - Collective knowledge enhances overall value.<hr />   - Explore, contribute, and build upon each other's skills.<hr />   - Leave a legacy of improvement.<hr /><hr />6. Importance of titles:<hr />   - Titles carry responsibility and accountability.<hr />   - Influence and decision-making extend beyond individual scope.<hr />   - Leadership is defined by contributions and the cultivation of future leaders.

133.title: Building A Solid High Performing Team
133.description: Sustainable growth companies are built by teams of shining constellations rather than just several bright stars. It all starts with recruiting.
133.spr_content: - Sustainable growth relies on collaborative teams ("constellations") not merely individual talents ("bright stars").  <hr />- Recruitment is the foundational step; it determines success or failure in leadership.  <hr />- Effective placement of team members is crucial; people’s core personalities are mostly fixed.  <hr />- Distinguish between skill evolution and personality change; attempts to alter personality fail.  <hr />- Toxicity must be minimized; leverage failures as learning opportunities.  <hr />- Employ agile methodologies for strategic advantages; embrace "divide and conquer" approaches.  <hr />- Incremental improvement and rapid learning benefit all business areas, including mundane tasks.  <hr />- Proper practice prevents resource wastage and supports consistent progress.

134.title: The Dwarves Runs By Ideas
134.description: We figure a small team is easier to share perspectives, update on what's happening and discuss different work aspects. Besides better communication, working cross functional creates a higher chance to understand the whole operation flow.
134.spr_content: - Operations structured in four branches: **Account** (client happiness), **PeopleOps** (resource allocation), **Human Resource** (recruitment and employee experience), **Communication** (information transmission).<hr />- Unique operational flow prioritizing minimal human intervention and small teams.<hr />- Small teams enhance perspective-sharing, updates, and dialogue across disciplines.<hr />- Cross-functional work improves comprehension of overall operations.<hr />- Emphasis on startup model: draft, execute, fail fast, learn, improve.<hr />- Goals: increase productivity and foster collaboration.<hr />- Vision: create a workplace where everyone thrives, generating exceptional ideas.<hr />- Focus on problem-solving capability; products emerge as obstacles are addressed.<hr />- Team motto aligns with distributing tech know-how for positive change.<hr />- Unified vision fosters understanding and enhances information flow.<hr />- Hierarchy minimized; ideas valued from all levels.<hr />- Ideas serve as solutions or optimizations; originate from daily challenges.<hr />- Avoidance of irrelevant ideas; importance of practical brainstorms.<hr />- Best ideas dictate leadership, regardless of tenure.<hr />- Core philosophy: contribution of new ideas is essential for participation.

135.title: Making Decision As A Team Member
135.description: Being able to make decision trains ourselves to accept responsibility with an open mind. Either it's a success or a failure, we move forward.
135.spr_content: - **Democracy Defined**: Decision-making power is given to the people, specifically your people. <hr />- **Respect & Responsibility**: Ensuring respect fosters shared responsibility, which mitigates risk. <hr />- **Flat Hierarchy**: Maintain a non-hierarchical structure where team members have control over their work.<hr />- **Empowerment**: Hire individuals who provide solutions, not just follow directions. <hr />- **Decision Ownership**: The individuals performing tasks should hold decision-making authority. <hr />- **3x2 Framework**: Every business decision must consider People, Customer, and Number; both Now and Then.<hr />- **Balance & Improvement**: Aim for decisions that enhance aspects without harming others. <hr />- **Encouragement & Independence**: Promote decision-making to stimulate creativity and ownership of ideas. <hr />- **Learning from Outcomes**: Accept failures as learning opportunities for growth and improvement.<hr />- **Collective Engagement**: Decision-making involves teamwork; engage others for insights and data. <hr />- **Information Sharing**: Seeking input enhances decision strength; collaboration strengthens outcomes.<hr />- **Responsibility Aversion**: People may fear responsibility, leading to hesitation in decision-making. <hr />- **Testing Approach**: Encourage a culture of trial and error to refine ideas and solutions.<hr />- **Reasoning Behind Decisions**: Focus on the "why" of proposals rather than just the "how" to ensure purpose-driven initiatives. <hr />- **Backup Scenarios**: Prepare contingency plans for potential failures to mitigate risks.

136.title: Estimation Guidelines
136.description: When we conduct an estimation, it is recommended to abandon the transitional “exact hours” assessment method, instead, use the story point based on the Fibonacci number (1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21…). The number expresses an estimation of the overall effort required to fully implement a backlog item or any piece of work.
136.spr_content: - Estimation method: transition from "exact hours" to story points, using Fibonacci sequence.<hr />- Story points represent effort required for backlog items.<hr />- Complexity, uncertainty, and effort are key factors in estimation.<hr /><hr />| Story Points | Reference                          | Uncertainty           | Risk                          | Efforts                     | FE Example                                            | BE Example                              |<hr />|--------------|------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------------------|-----------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------|<hr />| **1**        | < 0.25 days, single FE or BE      | Low (100% clear)      | Low                           | < 1 hour                   | Small UI updates, minimal impact                     | Configurations only                     |<hr />| **2**        | < 0.5 days, more FE or BE work    | Low (some changes)    | Low                           | 0.5 - 1 day                | Calculate numbers, small UI change on multiple screens| Minor API changes                       |<hr />| **3**        | ~ 1 day, logic changes             | Low (check logic)     | Low                           | ~ 1 working day            | -                                                    | -                                       |<hr />| **5**        | 1-2 days, simple new endpoint      | Low - Medium           | Medium                        | ~ 3 working days           | -                                                    | -                                       |<hr />| **8**        | Half a Sprint, multiple endpoints   | Medium - High         | Medium to High               | ~ 5 working days           | -                                                    | -                                       |<hr />| **13**       | POC work, architecture changes     | High                   | High                          | Break down if > 1 week     | -                                                    | -                                       |<hr /><hr />- Each story point indicates increasing complexity and uncertainty.<hr />- Low numbers denote simple tasks, while higher numbers denote greater risk and effort.

137.title: Organize team know-how with Zettelkasten Method
137.description: At memo.d.foundation, we use the Zettelkasten Method to enhance engagement by capturing one idea per note and connecting concepts with tags and citations. This method improves clarity, consistency, memorization, and reduces bias. We organize notes with a tag system and content map in Obsidian, making it easy for readers to navigate and see connections between topics.
137.spr_content: - Knowledge acquisition involves integrating existing knowledge with new information.<hr />- The Zettelkasten Method promotes idea organization and engagement through notes.<hr />  <hr />### Zettelkasten Method Overview<hr />- Captures one idea per note, centralizing knowledge storage.<hr />- Utilizes tagging and URL citations for related concept connections.<hr /><hr />### Components of a Note<hr />1. **Unique Identifier**: Distinct address for each note (e.g., unique ID, URL).<hr />2. **Body of the Zettel**: Encapsulates a single piece of knowledge.<hr />3. **References**: Source citation or personal thought acknowledgment at the note's end.<hr /><hr />### Types of Notes in Zettelkasten<hr />1. **Fleeting Notes**: Quick, transient captures of thoughts and ideas for later refinement.<hr />2. **Literature Notes**: Key points from readings, focusing on single ideas.<hr />3. **Permanent Notes**: Long-term, interconnected notes summarizing grouped ideas.<hr />4. **Reference Notes**: Connective notes serving as a directory for related information.<hr /><hr />### Benefits of the Zettelkasten Method<hr />- **Clarity in Thinking**: Writing clarifies and coherently expresses thoughts.<hr />- **Consistent Development**: Prevents mental leaps, ensuring idea continuity.<hr />- **Improved Memorization**: Physical recording aids retention.<hr />- **Bias Prevention**: Fixed written thoughts mitigate hindsight bias.<hr /><hr />### Implementation by the Team<hr />- **Tag System**: Homepage displays tags; each tag links to related posts, enhancing content discoverability and connection.<hr />- **Map of Content**: Organized using Obsidian; stores markdown files categorized by topic, showcasing interconnected notes for flexible organization.

138.title: Forward Proxy
138.description: A forward proxy is a server that sits between user devices and the internet.
138.spr_content: - **Forward Proxy**: intermediary server for client-internet communication.<hr />  - **Functions**:<hr />    - Client protection<hr />    - Circumvent browse restrictions<hr />    - Content access control<hr /><hr />- **Reverse Proxy**: intermediary server for client-web server communication.<hr />  - **Functions**:<hr />    - Server protection<hr />    - Load balancing across servers<hr />    - Static content caching<hr />    - SSL communication handling (encryption/decryption)<hr /><hr />- **Contrast**:<hr />  - Forward: client-centric; inhibits direct internet access.<hr />  - Reverse: server-centric; optimizes server requests. <hr /><hr />- **Purpose**: Enhance security, manage traffic, and facilitate content delivery.<hr />

139.title: Multi-column index in DB
139.spr_content: - Composite indexes allow indexing on multiple columns in a database.<hr />- Correct column order in index definition is critical for performance.<hr />- A single composite index can improve query speed for multiple types of queries.<hr />- Example table structure:<hr />  - Primary key on `id`.<hr />  - Composite index named `name` on `(col1, col2, col3)`.<hr />- Queries benefiting from the index:<hr />  - Lookups specifying `col1`.<hr />  - Lookups specifying `col1` and `col2`.<hr />  - Lookups specifying all three columns: `col1`, `col2`, `col3`.<hr />- Queries not benefiting from the index:<hr />  - Lookups starting with a column not at the leftmost position of the index (e.g., only `col2` or `col2` and `col3`).<hr />- Optimizer uses any leftmost prefix of the composite index for efficient lookups.

140.title: Erlang Finite State Machine
140.description: The Power of Finite State Machines
140.spr_content: - Finite State Machines (FSMs): Model system behavior.<hr />- Erlang: Language for concurrency, fault tolerance, distributed computing.<hr />- Advantages of Erlang for FSMs:<hr />  1. Concurrency: Lightweight processes, efficient message-passing.<hr />  2. Fault Tolerance: Error detection and recovery mechanisms.<hr />  3. Distributed Computing: Supports easy scaling and resilience.<hr />  <hr />- Catch Chicken Machine: Example FSM in Erlang.<hr />  - **States**:<hr />    - Idle: Waiting for command.<hr />    - Searching: Actively looking for chicken.<hr />    - Catching: Attempting to catch chicken.<hr />    - Resting: Break after catch failure or success.<hr />  <hr />- Implementation Practices:<hr />  1. Define States and Events:<hr />     - Use defines for states and events.<hr />  2. State Transition Logic:<hr />     - Utilize pattern matching for transitions.<hr />  3. Concurrency and Messaging:<hr />     - Handle transitions with a message loop.<hr />  4. Fault Tolerance:<hr />     - Error handling to recover from unexpected states.<hr />  <hr />- Benefits of Erlang for FSMs:<hr />  - Scalability: Manage multiple concurrent processes.<hr />  - Reliability: Graceful recovery from errors.<hr />  - Clarity: Easy-to-understand pattern matching and definitions.<hr /><hr />- Conclusion: Erlang excels in FSM implementation, with practical benefits evident in the Catch Chicken Machine. Emphasizes concurrency, fault tolerance, and maintainability.

141.title: Materialized View Pattern
141.description: Materialized view is the cache of views. It pre-computes, stores, and optimizes data access when created, and automatically refreshes to ensure real-time data availability.
141.spr_content: - **Materialized View:** Acts as a cached view, pre-computes and optimizes data, enhancing access speed. <hr />- **Normal View:** Provides flexibility but lacks performance improvement for data access. <hr />- **Use Cases:** Essential in data warehouses for complex queries on large tables. Reduces overhead from expensive joins and aggregations. <hr />- **Efficiency:** Best for anticipated queries leveraging repeated subquery results. <hr />- **Refresh Strategies:** Two primary types:<hr />  1. **Complete Refresh:**<hr />     - Deletes old data, inserts new data, commits transaction.<hr />     - Users can access old data during refresh.<hr />     - Slow for large datasets.<hr />  <hr />  2. **Fast Refresh (incremental):**<hr />     - Requires materialized view logs on source tables.<hr />     - Must meet multiple preconditions; debugging possible with dbms_mview.explain_mview.<hr />     - Generally quicker than complete refresh. <hr />- **References:** Informative URLs provided for detailed understanding.

142.title: How to talk to ChatGPT effectively
142.description: This post presents technique to improve the your output when prompting ChatGPT.
142.spr_content: - **Interacting with ChatGPT**: Engage in text-based conversation with AI; prompts can include various elements like instructions and examples for better output.<hr /><hr />- **Importance of Prompt Quality**: The effectiveness of AI responses is heavily influenced by the clarity and detail of user prompts.<hr /><hr />- **Strategies for Effective Communication**:<hr />  1. **Define Objective**: Clearly state the desired outcome—information, creativity, problem-solving.<hr />  2. **Clarity and Conciseness**: Use simple language to enhance AI understanding.<hr />  3. **Provide Context**: Include background information relevant to the prompt without excess.<hr />  4. **Experiment and Iterate**: Refine prompts based on responses to find optimal wording.<hr />  5. **Consider Audience**: Tailor prompts to the needs of the expected users of the AI’s response.<hr />  6. **Evaluate and Adapt**: Continuously assess and adjust prompts for improved performance.<hr /><hr />- **Effective Prompt Principles**:<hr />  - **Give Direction**: Describe style and context; use commands (e.g., "Write", "Summarize").<hr />  - **Specify Format**: Detail expectations for results and structure.<hr />  - **Provide Examples**: Enhance clarity with sample inputs or formats.<hr />  - **Evaluate Quality**: Identify and analyze the quality of responses to improve future prompts.<hr />  - **Divide Labor**: Break complex goals into manageable, sequential tasks.<hr /><hr />- **Prompt Patterns**:<hr />  1. **Persona**: Simulate expert outputs; e.g., “Act as an expert to explain X.”<hr />  2. **Template**: Define a structure for responses, ensuring consistent output format.<hr />  3. **Recipe**: Outline a step-by-step sequence for achieving specific tasks.<hr />  4. **Context Control**: Instruct AI to remember critical conversation details for coherence.<hr />  5. **Interaction**: Allow AI to gather necessary information through targeted questions to arrive at comprehensive responses.

143.file_path: playground/00_fleeting/Why Hollywood and gaming struggle with AI.md
143.title: Why Hollywood and gaming struggle with AI
143.description: Why Hollywood and gaming struggle with AI
143.spr_content: - Incumbent entertainment and gaming companies face friction with generative AI.<hr />- Startups have opportunities to innovate in this space.<hr />- **"If it ain't broke, don't fix it"**: Established franchises hesitant to disrupt successful models.<hr />- Preference for **"bolt on" AI**: Companies prefer integrating AI features into existing products rather than reinventing them.<hr />- **Legal pushback**: Concerns over IP ownership and copyright issues hinder AI adoption.<hr />- **Creative resistance**: Fear among artists and designers that AI will disrupt traditional work processes.<hr />- **Talent acquisition challenge**: High demand and cost for top AI engineers make recruitment difficult for big companies.

144.title: Explaining Gradient Descent in Machine Learning with a simple analogy
144.description: Gradient descent is a fundamental optimization algorithm in machine learning. It's a way for models to learn from data and improve their accuracy by gradually adjusting their internal settings. Think of it like carefully descending a hill to find the lowest point—each small step you take brings you closer to the best possible solution.
144.spr_content: - **Gradient Descent**: Optimization algorithm; essential for machine learning.<hr />- **Analogy**: Navigating a foggy mountain to find the lowest point.<hr />- **The Hill**: Mathematical function; represents error of model predictions.<hr />- **Lowest Point**: Optimal solution; minimal error in learning.<hr />- **Your Steps**: <hr />  - Starting Point: Initial model parameters; unknown if optimal.<hr />  - Looking Around: Evaluate slope (gradient); direction of steepest descent.<hr />  - Taking a Step: Small parameter adjustments; move toward lower error.<hr />  - Repeat: Iterative process; continue until achieving minimum error.<hr />- **In Machine Learning**:<hr />  - The Hill: Represents model errors (e.g., misclassifying cats/dogs).<hr />  - Lowest Point: Ideal model; learns best from data.<hr />  - Steps: Incremental updates to model parameters for improvement.<hr />  - Looking Around: Assessing model's performance and refining guesses.<hr />  - Repeat: Continuous refinement until optimal learning is reached.<hr />- **Summary**: Gradient descent is a methodical approach to minimize prediction errors, akin to descending a hill to locate hidden treasure.

145.title: Rust Trait
145.description: Rust's **trait** system is a powerful feature that enables developers to define shared behavior across different types. Traits play a crucial role in achieving code reusability, abstraction, and flexibility...
145.spr_content: - Rust's **trait** system: enables shared behavior across types, fosters code reuse, abstraction, flexibility.  <hr />- **Traits**: collections of methods defining capabilities without dictating internal structure.  <hr />- **Analogy**: Similar to `interfaces` in other languages; promotes generic and adaptable code.  <hr /><hr />```rust<hr />trait Shape {<hr />    fn area(&self) -> f64;<hr />}<hr />```<hr />- **Shape trait**: example with `area` method for shared behavior.  <hr /><hr />- **Implementation**: Types implement traits using the `impl` keyword.  <hr />```rust<hr />struct Circle {<hr />    radius: f64,<hr />}<hr />impl Shape for Circle {<hr />    fn area(&self) -> f64 {<hr />        std::f64::consts::PI * self.radius * self.radius<hr />    }<hr />}<hr />```<hr />- `Circle` implements `Shape`, providing its own `area`.  <hr /><hr />- **Default Implementation**: Traits can have default methods; types can override them.  <hr />```rust<hr />trait Shape {<hr />    fn area(&self) -> f64;<hr />    fn perimeter(&self) -> f64 { 0.0 } // Default perimeter<hr />}<hr />```<hr />- Default `perimeter` allows automatic implementation unless overridden.  <hr /><hr />- **Traits as Parameters**: Enabling polymorphism; functions can accept any type implementing a trait.  <hr />```rust<hr />fn print_area(shape: impl Shape) {<hr />    println!("Area: {}", shape.area());<hr />}<hr />```<hr />- `print_area`: works with various shapes.  <hr /><hr />- **Trait Bound**: Specify generic types must implement certain traits.  <hr />```rust<hr />fn print_area<T: Shape>(shape: T) {<hr />    println!("Area: {}", shape.area());<hr />}<hr />```<hr />- `print_area` accepts any type `T` that implements `Shape`.  <hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**: Traits in Rust facilitate shared behavior; understanding their implementation, default behavior, function parameters, and trait bounds enhances modularity and adaptability in Rust code.

146.title: Sign-in Form Best Practices
146.spr_content: - Use semantic HTML: `<form>`, `<input>`, `<label>`, `<button>`.  <hr />- Label each input with `<label>` for accessibility.  <hr />- Utilize attributes: `type`, `name`, `autocomplete`, `required` for built-in browser features.  <hr />- Assign stable values to `name` and `id` attributes for consistency.  <hr />- Isolate sign-in in a dedicated `<form>` element.  <hr />- Confirm successful submission by redirecting or simulating navigation.  <hr />- Set `autocomplete="new-password"` and `id="new-password"` for sign-up and reset-password forms.  <hr />- Assign `autocomplete="current-password"` and `id="current-password"` for sign-in password.  <hr />- Implement Show password functionality for user convenience.  <hr />- Use `aria-label` and `aria-describedby` for enhanced accessibility of password inputs.  <hr />- Avoid asking users to repeat inputs (e.g., email or password).  <hr />- Design forms to prevent mobile keyboards from obscuring inputs and buttons.  <hr />- Ensure mobile friendliness: legible text, appropriately sized touch targets.  <hr />- Maintain branding and styling consistency in sign-up and sign-in pages.  <hr />- Conduct real-world testing alongside lab testing: incorporate analytics and performance metrics.  <hr />- Test forms across multiple browsers and devices to account for varied behaviors.

147.title: Founder Liquidity
147.description: Founder liquidity is a secret that founders and investors don't want you to know
147.spr_content: - Venture-backed founders justify 10x-1000x equity disparities by claiming significant personal risk and effort.<hr />- Founders' risk narrative is central to Silicon Valley mythology, portraying them as heroic figures overcoming obstacles.<hr />- Early employees face similar risks, yet receive disproportionately less equity and liquidity.<hr />- **Founder liquidity**: Founders often sell shares during funding rounds, securing personal financial stability while building the company.<hr />- This practice is obscure, undermining the "all-in" founder narrative, which garners sympathy and attracts talent.<hr />- Example: Adam Neumann (WeWork) cashed out over $2B while employees received nothing for their equity.<hr />- Employee perceptions are skewed by secrecy around founder liquidity.<hr />- Misconceptions include beliefs that liquidity harms morale, founders take far more risk than employees, and liquidity could deter future investments.<hr />- Journalist's experience highlighted that knowledge of founder liquidity did not negatively impact morale.<hr />- The journalist became a founder, realizing similar risk levels exist for early employees.<hr />- As a founder, intention to equitably balance risk through transparency, generous equity, and shared liquidity opportunities.<hr />- Innovations include a 20% employee option pool, 3-month vesting cliff, and 10-year option exercise window.<hr />- Advocates for transparency in funding announcements regarding founder liquidity to correct misperceptions.<hr />- Employees should regularly inquire about founders' liquidity decisions to understand their risk position—encouraging equity and compensation conversations.<hr />- If employees recognize increased risk relative to founders, it may prompt requests for adjustments in compensation or equity stakes.

148.title: Invoking component functions in React
148.description: What happens if you invoked the component function directly in React?
148.spr_content: - Invoking a component function directly in React violates the Rules of Hooks.<hr />- ExampleComponent uses useState for managing local state.<hr />- Direct invocation integrates ExampleComponent into the App, creating a super component.<hr />- Invoking it directly treats ExampleComponent as a custom hook, leading to inconsistent hook count.<hr />- Initially, App renders once, the show state is false, and only one hook is used.<hr />- Clicking the button sets show to true, rendering ExampleComponent which adds a second hook.<hr />- This action triggers the "Render more hooks than during the previous render" error.<hr />- To avoid errors, use JSX syntax: `<ExampleComponent />`, ensuring the component's lifecycle and hooks are properly managed.<hr />- JSX translates to `React.createElement(ExampleComponent, null)`, maintaining proper React component behavior and state management.

149.title: How to deal with technical debt in Scrum
149.description: How to deal with Technical debt in Scrum
149.spr_content: - Technical debt affects Scrum teams.<hr />- Identify sources: outdated tech, inadequate testing, poor documentation.<hr />- Prioritize high-impact items for value delivery.<hr />- Create a plan: refactor code, update tech, improve testing.<hr />- Integrate technical debt resolution in sprints.<hr />- Dedicate sprint time for addressing technical debt.<hr />- Monitor and track progress of technical debt efforts.<hr />- Adjust plans based on tracking results.<hr />- Communicate with stakeholders on technical debt strategies.<hr />- Align team and stakeholders for unified goals.  <hr />- #scrum #technicaldebt #projectmanagement

150.title: Automata
150.description: Things about automata that devs should know
150.spr_content: - **Finite State Automata (FSA)**: Algebraic structure for modeling systems with a defined set of states and transitions. <hr />- **Formal Components**: Expressed as `F = ⟨Σ, S, s0, F, δ⟩`, where `Σ` = input alphabet, `S` = states, `s0` = start state, `F` = accepting states, `δ` = state transition function.<hr />- **Concrete Representation**: Effective for illustrating paths from starting state to ending states, exemplified by regular expressions like AB+C.<hr />- **Visualization**: States can be represented graphically; transitions emphasize the relationship between actions and outcomes.<hr />- **Utility for Programmers**: Valuable as a thinking tool for modeling systems with multiple states. <hr />- **Applications**: Useful in designing applications that require clear state transitions in workflows, ensuring processes occur in the correct order.<hr />- **Finite State Machine (FSM)** vs. **Finite Automata (FA)**: Both terms refer to the same concept. 'Finite' signifies a limited number of states.<hr />- **Automata Functionality**: Automata automate computation tasks; once transition rules are defined, no additional intelligence is required.<hr />- **Transition Function (`δ:Q×Σ → Q`)**: Describes state changes based on input symbols; Cartesian product links states and symbols.<hr />- **State Representation**: Transition function can be depicted via transition tables, graphs, or mapping rules.<hr />- **State Machine vs. Workflow**: State machines are event-driven, driven by external events; workflows focus on task completion progression.<hr />- **DFA (Deterministic Finite Automaton)**: Always follows one path for states—efficient, strict, clear state transitions.<hr />- **NFA (Non-deterministic Finite Automaton)**: Explores multiple paths simultaneously—flexible, but may take longer to determine valid paths.<hr />- **Key Differences**: DFA is faster but limited in exploration; NFA is flexible but potentially slower due to simultaneous evaluation of options.

151.title: Migration Planning
151.description: Migration planning is a crucial part of any software development project, especially when migrating to a new database or platform.
151.spr_content: **Migration Plan Considerations:**<hr />1. Minimize downtime.<hr />2. Ensure data consistency.<hr />3. Develop a rollback plan.<hr />4. Implement observable and measurable metrics.<hr />5. Maintain team awareness throughout the process.<hr /><hr />**Common Steps:**<hr />1. Initiate dual reads/writes; use the old database as primary.<hr />2. Perform data backfilling.<hr />3. Compare and validate the new database against the old one.<hr />4. Transition to dual reads/writes; now the new database is primary.<hr />5. Decommission and remove the old database.

152.title: Error Handling Patterns
152.description: Quick note on error handling patterns in programming languages
152.spr_content: - **Error Handling Importance**: Critical for ensuring correct application behavior amidst unexpected inputs or conditions.<hr />  <hr />- **Return Codes/Status Codes**: <hr />  - Basic error handling; common in low-level languages like C.<hr />  - Function returns success (e.g., `0`) or failure (e.g., `-1`).<hr />  - Caller responsible for checking return value; missing checks can lead to silent bugs.<hr /><hr />- **Exceptions (Try-Catch)**: <hr />  - Modern structured error handling; used in languages like Python, Java, C#.<hr />  - Program throws exceptions, caught in `try-catch` blocks.<hr />  - Ensures separation of normal logic and error handling; use specific exceptions, avoid swallowing them.<hr /><hr />- **Error Objects or Results**: <hr />  - Forces return of an object indicating success or error.<hr />  - Common in functional languages like Rust and Swift.<hr />  - Promotes explicit handling of success and errors, reducing missed error handling.<hr /><hr />- **Assertions**: <hr />  - Debugging tool to enforce conditions; program crashes if assertion fails.<hr />  - Not for production error handling; suited for development.<hr /><hr />- **Callbacks (Error-First)**: <hr />  - Common in asynchronous environments like Node.js.<hr />  - First parameter is error; check error first in callbacks.<hr />  - Can lead to "callback hell" with nested operations.<hr /><hr />- **Promise-Based Error Handling**: <hr />  - Evolved from callbacks; cleaner asynchronous code handling.<hr />  - Uses `.then()` for success, `.catch()` for errors.<hr />  - Improves readability, but can complicate debugging with misplaced `.catch()`.<hr /><hr />- **Pattern Matching**: <hr />  - Utilized in functional languages to handle computation outcomes.<hr />  - Decomposes data structures; requires handling all possible cases.<hr /><hr />- **Panic (Crash)**: <hr />  - Used for non-recoverable errors in languages like Rust and Go.<hr />  - Results in program crash; reserved for critical scenarios, not user input errors.

153.title: Case study: Write-heavy scalable and reliable inventory platform
153.description: How Doordash designed a successful write-heavy scalable and reliable inventory platform
153.spr_content: - **Case Study:** Development of a write-heavy, scalable, and reliable inventory platform.  <hr />- **Technical Requirements:** <hr />  - High scalability. <hr />  - High reliability. <hr />  - Low latency. <hr />  - High observability.  <hr />- **Database Table Optimization Strategies:**  <hr />  - Natural primary key creation from business parameters to enhance query efficiency.  <hr />  - Clean up database indexes: <hr />    - Add missing indexes for all queries.  <hr />    - Remove unnecessary indexes.  <hr />  - Reduce column count by consolidating frequently updated columns into a single JSONB column; weigh pros and cons based on use cases.  <hr />  - Implement Time-To-Live (TTL) for fast-growing tables to manage data retention effectively.  <hr />  - Batch and rewrite queries within a single SQL request to save query per second (QPS) for downstream services.
153.tags: doordash inventory-platform low-latency observability reliability scalability write-heavy

154.title: React Fiber
154.description: Fiber is the new reconciliation algorithm since React 16, a completely backward-compatible rewrite of the old reconciler (Stack Reconciler).
154.spr_content: - React Fiber: new reconciliation algorithm since React 16.<hr />- Backward-compatible rewrite of Stack Reconciler.<hr />- Purpose: improved performance by overcoming call stack limits.<hr />- Allows rendering work division into manageable chunks.<hr />- Supports work pausing or restarting conditionally.<hr />- Enables priority control over rendering tasks.<hr />- User actions prioritized over less critical background functions.<hr />- Enhances suitability for advanced UI elements: animations, layouts, gestures.<hr />- Facilitates a fluid user experience through chunk management.<hr />- Previous Stack Reconciler: synchronous reconciliation, rendering intertwined.<hr />- Resulted in lagging inputs, choppy frame rates.<hr />- Fiber separates reconciliation from rendering, enhancing app performance.

155.title: Go JSON parser: number <-> interface
155.description: TLDR; becareful when using  map[string]interface{} to hold json number value, use custom decoder with newDecoder.UseNumber() to decode the json string.
155.spr_content: - Go JSON parsing can convert numbers to interface{} incorrectly.<hr />- Using `map[string]interface{}` leads to JSON numbers being treated as float64.<hr />- Example shows loss of precision when marshaling and unmarshaling large integers (`int64`).<hr />- Default behavior: Go's JSON package defaults to `float64` for numbers in `interface{}`.<hr />- Custom solution: Utilize `json.NewDecoder(...).UseNumber()` to maintain exact number representation.<hr />- Steps: <hr />  1. Create a decoder with `UseNumber()`.<hr />  2. Decode into a `map[string]interface{}`.<hr />  3. Result preserves original number (`int64`) without conversion to float64.<hr />- Reference link provided for Go's JSON decoding method.

156.title: Error Messaging
156.description: What makes a bad error message
156.spr_content: **Bad Error Messages:**  <hr />- Inappropriate tone undermines user trust.  <hr />- Technical jargon alienates users, causing confusion.  <hr />- Passing the blame shifts responsibility away from the product, frustrating users.  <hr />- Being generic fails to inform or assist, leaving users uninformed.  <hr /><hr />**Good Error Messages:**  <hr />- Clearly state what happened and why, creating understanding.  <hr />- Provide reassurance to calm user anxiety during errors.  <hr />- Embody empathy to connect with users emotionally.  <hr />- Offer solutions to help users resolve the issue effectively.  <hr />- Always present a way out, enabling users to continue their tasks.

158.title: Subscription Pricing Models
158.spr_content: - **Freemium Model**: Attracts users; free basic version -> encourages paid upgrades. Example: Evernote's Basic, Premium, Business plans. Use: Market share growth, new market testing, viral product potential.<hr /><hr />- **Pay per Quantity Model**: Charges based on unit count (e.g., seats, emails). Example: Help Scout - $20/user/month post-free plan. Use: Predictable costs for scaling, targeting large organizations.<hr /><hr />- **Pay per Active User Model**: Charges for users only when active. Example: Slack's active user billing. Use: Appeals to large enterprises, promotes fair billing.<hr /><hr />- **Flat-fee Model**: Recurring flat fee for a single plan/product. Example: Hubspot's fixed monthly tiers. Use: Generates consistent revenue, appeals to risk-averse customers.<hr /><hr />- **Pay-as-you-go (Usage-based) Model**: Charges based on usage with tiered variations. Example: Postmark's volume pricing for emails. Use: Value-based pricing, adapts to demand.<hr /><hr />- **Tiered Model**: Different price points for varying usage tiers. Example: ManageWiz's tiered unit pricing. Use: Structured pricing for diverse quantities.<hr /><hr />- **Volume Model**: Per-unit pricing decreases with quantity purchased. Example: Jira's volume-based pricing. Use: Economies of scale, incentivizes bulk purchases.<hr /><hr />- **Stair-step Model**: Fixed prices for predefined usage ranges. Example: Trello's pricing by ranges. Use: Clarity in pricing, simple understanding.<hr /><hr />- **'Name Your Price' or Custom Pricing**: Negotiated custom prices for individual customers. Example: Jira's custom enterprise deals. Use: High-touch sales, tailored pricing for large clients.<hr /><hr />- **Hybrid Model**: Combines various pricing models. Example: DocuSign's user number and document limits. Use: Multi-dimensional value extraction, upgrade opportunities.<hr /><hr />- **À la carte Model**: Customers select specific features/services to pay for. Example: Shopify's feature choices. Use: Products with diverse use cases, flexibility in feature selection.

159.title: The Best of CSS TLDR
159.description: Tailwind is not another Bootstrap, a `justify-center` class maps exactly to 1 line of css code, you have total control over what is being shipped to the user, whereas a `.btn` class in Bootstrap expands to +50 line of css styles and custom variables, you can customize it but it will not be a joyful experience.
159.spr_content: 1. UI libraries fall into three main categories:<hr />   - **Pure:** Utilizes pure CSS with no JavaScript; focuses on appearance (e.g., Tailwind, SASS). What you code is what you get when compiled.<hr />   - **Behavioral:** Composed of pure JavaScript, focusing on accessibility and functionality; unstyled components for consistent behavior across browsers (e.g., HeadlessUI, Radix).<hr />   - **Style System:** Combines predefined components with a layer of pure CSS; opinionated design by authors dictate aesthetics (e.g., TailwindUI, Bootstrap).<hr /><hr />2. **Bootstrap vs. Tailwind:** <hr />   - Tailwind offers granular control with utility classes, e.g., `justify-center` corresponds to a single CSS rule.<hr />   - Bootstrap classes (e.g., `.btn`) expand, adding significant CSS weight, making customization difficult and cumbersome.<hr /><hr />3. **Material UI (MUI):**<hr />   - MUI serves as a hybrid of behavioral and style system categories.<hr />   - It provides predefined components with preset styles and JavaScript for interaction.<hr />   - Customization becomes complex when trying to achieve unique designs beyond given examples.<hr /><hr />4. **Recommendation:**<hr />   - Use Tailwind when uncertain; it aids in learning and improves output quality.<hr />   - For beginners, promotes faster CSS learning; for experienced users, enhances development speed.

160.title: Behavior Driven Development
160.description: Behavior Driven Development (BDD) is a software development process that encourages collaboration among developers, QA, and non-technical stakeholders.
160.spr_content: - BDD emphasizes collaboration between stakeholders to clarify system behavior through user stories.<hr />- Start with a user story for a proposed change, discussing concrete examples to uncover expectations.<hr />- Document these examples in an automated format to reach consensus, ensuring clarity on requirements.<hr />- Implement behavior as outlined in the documented examples, initiating with automated tests to drive development.<hr />- Goals of BDD: <hr />  - Facilitate rapid, small-scale changes.<hr />  - Enable iterative process by backing up for more information when necessary.<hr />  - Automate New examples to gather feedback efficiently.<hr />- Example of BDD: User Login feature detailing scenarios for valid credentials.<hr />- Common pitfalls: <hr />  - Adopting BDD/TDD only during the testing phase is inadequate; early integration is essential.<hr />  - BDD aids in revealing different scenarios, enriching requirements and implementation phases.<hr />- BDD incorporates ubiquitous language from Domain-Driven Design, fostering shared understanding among team members.

161.title: Go extension interface pattern
161.description: Note about using Go extension interface pattern
161.spr_content: - **Extension Interface Pattern**: Embeds one interface within another for feature enhancement without altering original code.<hr />- **Purpose**: Adds functionality flexibly, allowing for non-intrusive modifications.<hr />- **Extending Packages**: Works with third-party packages to avoid forking; augments minimal interfaces.<hr />- **Testing Utility**: Facilitates behavior mocking or adaptation for testing; useful for logging and metrics.<hr />- **Examples**:<hr />  - **Extending `io.Reader` & `io.Writer`**: Allows features like logging or compression through embedding.<hr />    - **LoggingWriter Example**: Wraps `io.Writer` to log data writes without modifying `io.Writer`.<hr />  - **HTTP Middleware**: Extends `http.Handler` for logging requests.<hr />    - **LoggingMiddleware Example**: Wraps a handler to log HTTP requests.<hr />  - **Database Extensions**: Enhances `sql.DB` with workings like logging queries.<hr />    - **LoggingDB Example**: Logs executed SQL queries while maintaining `sql.DB` integrity.<hr />  - **Caching in HTTP Clients**: Implements caching for `http.Client`.<hr />    - **CachingClient Example**: Wraps `http.Client` to cache responses.<hr />  - **Timeouts in HTTP Requests**: Adds timeout functionality to `http.Request`.<hr />    - **TimeoutRequest Example**: Wraps requests to apply context timeouts.<hr />  - **Decorators for `fmt.Stringer`**: Enhances string representations with added prefixes.<hr />    - **PrefixedStringer Example**: Adds a prefix to output of `fmt.Stringer`.<hr />- **Optional API Functionality**: Allows base interface use while leveraging extended interfaces when available.<hr />- **Dynamic Type Checking**: Uses type assertions to check for extended behaviors at runtime.<hr />- **Efficiency**: Leverages extended interfaces (e.g., `io.StringWriter`) for optimized operations if available.

162.title: How does Go achieve type safety when it enables generics?
162.description: A quick note on How does Go achieve type safety when it enables generics
162.spr_content: - Go introduced generics in version 1.18 (March 2022).<hr />- Generics enhance flexibility and reusability without compromising type safety.<hr />- Previously, Go was simple and type-safe but lacked the flexibility seen in languages like Java, C#, and C++.<hr />- Generics were highly anticipated and represented a significant milestone for Go.<hr /><hr />**Key Concepts:**<hr />1. **Type Parameters**: <hr />   - Defined in square brackets `[]`, allowing functions/types to accept multiple types.<hr />   - Example: `func Print[T any](items []T) { ... }` where `T` is the type parameter and `any` is a default constraint.<hr /><hr />2. **Type Constraints**: <hr />   - Limit types that type parameters can represent, maintaining type safety.<hr />   - Interfaces or built-in constraints (e.g., `comparable`, `any`).<hr />   - Example: Custom interface `Stringer` ensuring compliance with specific method implementation.<hr /><hr />3. **Compile-Time Checking**: <hr />   - Go checks types at compile time to ensure compliance with constraints.<hr />   - Prevents compilation of programs with incorrect type usages.<hr /><hr />4. **Underlying Type Consistency**: <hr />   - Constraints like `comparable` ensure types can be compared appropriately, preventing runtime errors.<hr /><hr />5. **Explicit and Simple Type Inference**: <hr />   - Compiler infers type parameters when possible, retaining safety.<hr />   - Example: `func Add[T int | float64](a, b T) T { ... }` where type `T` is inferred for numerical operations.<hr /><hr />**Process Overview**:<hr />- Generic code is parsed → AST is created.<hr />- Type checking occurs, including constraint verification and type inference.<hr />- TypedAST compiles into executable code or instantiates for concrete types ensuring type safety.<hr /><hr />**Summary**:<hr />- Go achieves type safety through:<hr />  1. **Type parameters** for flexibility.<hr />  2. **Type constraints** enforcing type rules.<hr />  3. **Compile-time type checking** validating types.<hr />  4. **Type inference** ensuring safety during compilation.

163.title: Package first design
163.description: In Go, packages serve as the basic building blocks for creating modular, reusable, and maintainable software.
163.spr_content: - Go emphasizes **composition over inheritance** in software design.<hr />- Packages are fundamental for **modular, reusable**, and maintainable software.<hr />- Structure projects into **well-encapsulated packages** with clear purposes.<hr />- **Encapsulation**: By default, package symbols are private, exported with uppercase letters.<hr />- Separate concerns within packages for clarity (e.g., `http`, `router`, `db`).<hr />- Go's directory structure aligns with package-oriented design.<hr />- Testing: Include **unit tests** in the same directory as packages, using `_test.go` suffix.<hr />- Modularity enables the **creation of reusable building blocks**.<hr />- Steps for applying package-oriented development:<hr />  1. Identify **core domains** and reusable utilities (e.g., `users`, `orders`, `products`).<hr />  2. Design packages to be **self-contained** and purpose-driven.<hr />  3. Create **generalized, flexible functions** for broader application.<hr />  4. Use **interfaces** to decouple dependencies between packages.<hr />  5. Structure **utility packages** for wide applicability.<hr />  6. Document packages clearly for future reuse.<hr />  7. Write independent **unit tests** for functionality validation.<hr />  8. **Refactor regularly** to maintain focus and reusability.<hr />- Benefits:<hr />  - **Clean organization**: Small, focused packages reduce complexity.<hr />  - **Ease of reuse**: Packages can be shared across projects.<hr />  - **Enhanced maintainability**: Clear structure simplifies modifications.<hr />  - **Collaboration**: Teams can develop concurrently on different packages.<hr />  - **Simplified testing/debugging**: Modular design aids in testing specific functionalities.

164.title: Unit Testing Best Practices In Golang
164.description: An in-depth exploration of arrays and slices in Go, covering their differences, internal implementations, and key operations like append. Learn about fixed-length arrays, flexible slices, and how Go manages memory allocation for growing slices.
164.spr_content: - Backend engineering challenges involve writing test cases, especially in Go.<hr />- Effective testing techniques enhance unit tests and improve isolation via mocks.<hr />- Importance of testing: detects bugs, ensures maintainability, improves security and quality.<hr />- Benefits of unit testing:<hr />  - Early bug detection and resolution.<hr />  - Acts as a safety net for developers.<hr />  - Increases code quality.<hr />  - Helps identify code smells.<hr />- Golang testing framework details:<hr />  - User-friendly for unit tests, benchmarks, and examples.<hr />  - Supports multiple test types: performance, parallel, functional.<hr />- Writing a test suite in Golang:<hr />  - Use filename ending in _test.go, import "testing."<hr />  - Define test functions starting with TestXxx.<hr />  - Execute tests using `go test`.<hr />- Effective tests require:<hr />  - Testable code: clean, extendable, abstraction through interfaces.<hr />  - Clear naming conventions for test cases.<hr />  - Table-driven testing for better readability.<hr />- Use of interfaces and mocks results in:<hr />  - Decoupled code from dependencies.<hr />  - Isolated tests without file I/O/API calls.<hr />- Coverage of edge cases and boundary conditions is essential:<hr />  - Test extreme values, unexpected inputs, and corner cases.<hr />- Test coverage metrics:<hr />  - 0-20%: Very Poor, leads to unnoticed bugs.<hr />  - 21-40%: Poor, significant untested code.<hr />  - 41-60%: Acceptable, needs improvement.<hr />  - 61-80%: Good, catches most bugs.<hr />  - 81-100%: Very Good, rare bug occurrences.<hr />- Recommended coverage: 61-80%; focus on effective bug detection over metrics.<hr />- Tooling improvements: use mocking libraries and assertion tools like testify.<hr />- Conclusion emphasizes the ongoing nature of testing in development for reliability and maintainability.

165.title: Connecting Vim With Golang
